abstract.text: An object containing information for a score that was earned by the player.

inlineContent.text: Your game must authenticate a local player before you can use any Game Center classes. If there is no authenticated player, your game receives a
objects to post scores to a leaderboard on Game Center. When your game retrieves score information from a leaderboard, those scores are returned as
Scores and leaderboards work together to help you create a better game. Whenever a new
object is created, it is associated with a leaderboard. You must ensure that the score being sent to a leaderboard is compatible with the leaderboard scoring format set in App Store Connect. See
for information on how to create a leaderboard in App Store Connect.
To report a score to Game Center, your game allocates and initializes a new object, sets the
property to the score the player earned, and then calls the
method. The mechanism your game uses to calculate scores is up to you to design; scores are only compared within your game.

abstract.text: Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An
object provides a standard user interface to display achievement progress for the local player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
A completion block that provides information about the player who issues a challenge and the players who receive it.
The
class is used to respond to events related to challenges sent or received by the local player.
The object representing the currently signed-in iCloud user.
The system can’t complete the requested operation because the system hasn’t authorized the player.
Your game uses the
class to present a screen that allows the local player to send friend requests to other players.
The dashboard that allows players to access their Game Center data in your game.
A game session you can use to save game data, invite other players, and create turn-based and real-time game apps.
A user interface you can use to invite other users into a tvOS game session.
Information about a single score by a player on a leaderboard.
The
class provides a standard user interface that displays leaderboard scores to the player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
Provides a standard user interface to allow one iOS device to discover and connect to another.
An object containing information for a score that was earned by the player.
The leaderboard that this score belongs to.
Provides a challenge compose view controller with preselected player identifiers and a preformatted, player-editable message.
Provides a challenge compose view controller with pre-selected player identifiers and a preformatted, player-editable message.
Provides a challenge compose view controller with pre-selected player identifiers and a preformatted, player-editable message.
An integer value used by your game.
The date and time when the score was earned.
Returns the player’s score as a localized string.
Returns an initialized score object.
Returns an initialized score object using the local player and the current date.
Returns an initialized score object for the specified leaderboard and player.
Returns an initialized score object for the specified leaderboard and player.
Issues a score challenge to a set of players.
The identifier for the leaderboard.
The player who earned the score.
The player identifier for the player that earned the score.
The position of the score in the results of a leaderboard search.

Submits a list of scores and all eligible challenges.
Reports a score to Game Center.
A Boolean value that indicates whether this score should also update the default leaderboard.
The score earned by the player.
A
object provides the ability to discover and connect to nearby iOS devices using Bluetooth or Wi-fi.
The
class is used to respond to important messages related to turn-based matches. To use it, call the
class method to get the singleton instance and assign an object that implements the
protocol to its
property. All methods are called on the main thread.
The delegate for the event handler.
Returns the shared instance of the event handler.
The
protocol is implemented by an object to receive notifications events for turn-based matches. All methods are called on the main thread.
A voice channel that allows players to speak with each other in a multiplayer game.
The
class allows your application to connect two iOS devices into a voice chat.
Confirm player credentials and device capabilities and check for account restrictions.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
